pr_title: fix: Uses pull query metrics for all paths, not just /query

timeline.message: fix: Uses pull query metrics for all paths, not just /query

timeline.bodyText: What about the existing streamedQueryResource.closeMetrics() call?
timeline.author: apurvam

replies.bodyText: I moved the method to pullQueryExecutor and then just call that.  Same logic being called, just in a different place.
replies.author: AlanConfluent

timeline.bodyText: There was a reason for these measurements to be in the StreamedQueryResource. They measure a more realistic latency that accounts also for query parsing etc. , basically all that happens before the request reaches the PullQueryExecutor.
timeline.author: vpapavas
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -223,13 +229,21 @@ public PullQueryResult execute(
           contextStacker,
           pullQueryMetrics);
 
-      return handlePullQuery(
+      final PullQueryResult result = handlePullQuery(
           statement,
           executionContext,
           serviceContext,
           pullQueryContext,
           routingOptions
       );
+

replies.bodyText:
My original thinking was that such CPU bound things like parsing should be an order of magnitude or two faster than IO like reading from disk or network.  I do recall that in earlier benchmarking, we didn't seem to be IO bound, but that's probably a separate issue.
If what we really want is latency for the whole endpoint, which I agree is preferable, it seems like it would be good to have a more generic latency metric for all resources -- that way we don't special case this.  Not sure if that's possible with Vert.x, but I imagine it is.  So as to keep consistency with existing metric naming and make it work with the websocket (which is probably harder to make generic), I'll stick to the pull query use case for now.  Ok, I'll change this part back and add in the web socket.
replies.author: AlanConfluent

replies.bodyText: That's a good point - might be worth asking @purplefox and/or googling about vert.x to see if there is a generic way to get metrics on all requests.  I know this is possible in Jetty, but don't know vert.x.
replies.author: big-andy-coates

     final RoutingFilterFactory routingFilterFactory = initializeRoutingFilterFactory(ksqlConfig,

+    final Boolean collectMetrics = ksqlConfig.getBoolean(

timeline.bodyText: Can we move this into the PullQueryExecutor constructor please, given its already being passed the ksqlConfig as a parameter?
timeline.author: big-andy-coates
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -698,8 +700,16 @@ static KsqlRestApplication buildApplication(
     final RoutingFilterFactory routingFilterFactory = initializeRoutingFilterFactory(ksqlConfig,
         heartbeatAgent, lagReportingAgent);
 
+    final Boolean collectMetrics = ksqlConfig.getBoolean(
+        KsqlConfig.KSQL_QUERY_PULL_METRICS_ENABLED);
+    final Optional<PullQueryExecutorMetrics> pullQueryMetrics = collectMetrics
+        ? Optional.of(new PullQueryExecutorMetrics(
+        ksqlEngine.getServiceId(),
+        ksqlConfig.getStringAsMap(KsqlConfig.KSQL_CUSTOM_METRICS_TAGS)))
+        : empty();
+

timeline.bodyText: nit: validate params that will be stored in object state; ensuring object does not get into an invalid state.
timeline.author: big-andy-coates

replies.bodyText: I now create it here rather than pass it in.
replies.author: AlanConfluent

timeline.author: big-andy-coates

timeline.bodyText: pullQueryMetrics is Optional. It should never be null`.
timeline.author: big-andy-coates

replies.bodyText: I agree, should have caught that.  This was just moved code.
replies.author: AlanConfluent

timeline.author: big-andy-coates

timeline.bodyText: Probably better to keep this as KsqlExecutionContext and pass in the service Id... less coupling.
timeline.author: big-andy-coates

timeline.bodyText:
Why not just have:

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                  pullQueryMetrics.ifPresent(metrics ->
          
          
            
                      metrics.recordLatency(Time.SYSTEM.nanoseconds() - startTimeNanos));
          
          
            
                  pullQueryMetrics.ifPresent(metrics ->
          
          
            
                      metrics.recordLatency(startTimeNanos));
          
      
    
    
  

And change recordLatency to take the end time in ns, encapsulating the Time.SYSTEM.nanoseconds() into a single place...?
timeline.author: big-andy-coates
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -223,13 +230,17 @@ public PullQueryResult execute(
           contextStacker,
           pullQueryMetrics);
 
-      return handlePullQuery(
+      final PullQueryResult result = handlePullQuery(
           statement,
-          executionContext,
+          ksqlEngine,
           serviceContext,
           pullQueryContext,
           routingOptions
       );
+
+      pullQueryMetrics.ifPresent(metrics ->
+          metrics.recordLatency(Time.SYSTEM.nanoseconds() - startTimeNanos));

timeline.bodyText: As suggested above, change to taking the end time, rather than the elapsed time?
timeline.author: big-andy-coates

timeline.bodyText: Can we go with a non-zero start time please?  Stick it in a constant, e.g. START_TIME = 1234L. Update tests to use START_TIME.
timeline.author: big-andy-coates

timeline.bodyText: Would be good to test its passing an appropriate start time here. Can we inject a clock?
timeline.author: big-andy-coates

       final Exception e = assertThrows(
           KsqlException.class,
-          () -> pullQueryExecutor.execute(query, engine.getServiceContext(), Optional.empty(),
-              Optional.empty())
+          () -> pullQueryExecutor.execute(query, engine.getServiceContext(), Optional.empty(), 0L)

timeline.author: big-andy-coates

replies.bodyText: I had removed the rate variable since it didn't appear to be read at all in practice, and since you had recommended removing it, but I'm now thinking you just meant the method recordRate.  Alright, will add this variable to the recordLatecy call and add back this test.
replies.author: AlanConfluent
